question: The company cost of capital is defined as the expected return on a portfolio of all the company’s outstanding debt and equity securities.
The weighted average cost of capital is the discount rate for the firm’s average-risk projects.
When estimating the weighted-average cost of capital, debt and equity enter at market value.
The market risk premium is the difference between the return on the market and the risk-free interest rate.
Each project, a company seeks to invest into, should be discounted by its own discount rate which considers the project’s appropriate risk.
“Pure plays” are firms in the same line of business as the project considered, not involved in any other type of business, and privately held.
Projects with long-term cash flows are less sensitive to changes in the risk-free rate or market risk premium.
Unbiased forecasts of project’s cash flows incorporate all possible outcomes, including those that are specific to the project and those that stem from economywide events.
The company cost of capital is the correct discount rate for any project a company considers, because high risks of some projects are offset by the low risk of other projects.
Interest payments and dividends are tax deductible.
WACC is based on a firm’s future characteristics.
When using the WACC one assumes that risks remain unchanged for the life of the project.
One key assumption of the APV approach is that the firm actively rebalances in order to maintain its debt ratio.
The APV method is most useful when side-costs are numerous and important.
There can never be more than one value of the IRR for any sequence of cash flows.
